title: 111_hr225
content: The Act is titled the "Emergency Homeownership and Equity Protection Act" and provides eligibility for relief. Section 109 of title 11, United States Code is amended to exclude certain debts from the computation, including debts secured by the debtor's principal residence if its value is below the secured debt limit. This amendment does not apply to chapter 13 cases where the debtor submits to the court. In chapter 13, a debtor can inform the court about receiving notice of foreclosure on their principal residence. SEC. 3. AUTHORITY TO MODIFY CERTAIN MORTGAGES. Section 1322(b) of title 11, United States Code is amended to allow modification of rights for a loan secured by the debtor's principal residence before the Emergency Homeownership and Equity Protection Act, in case of foreclosure notice, to provide for payment of the secured claim amount and adjust interest rates. Section 1322(b) of title 11, United States Code is amended to allow modification of rights for a loan secured by the debtor's principal residence. This includes prohibiting, reducing, or delaying adjustments to the interest rate, extending the repayment period up to 40 years, and providing for the payment of accruing interest after the order for relief. The amendment allows for modification of a loan secured by the debtor's principal residence, including adjustments to interest rates, extending repayment period up to 40 years, and payment of accruing interest after the relief order. SEC. 4. COMBATING EXCESSIVE FEES. Section 1322(c) of title 11, the United States Code, is amended to state that the debtor, their property, and property of the estate are not liable for certain fees, costs, or charges related to a debt secured by the debtor's principal residence, unless specific conditions are met. The debtor, their property, and property of the estate are not liable for certain fees, costs, or charges related to a debt secured by the debtor's principal residence unless specific conditions are met, including giving notice within a specified timeframe and ensuring the fees are lawful, reasonable, and secured by property of greater value. Failure to give notice results in a waiver of any claim for fees, costs, or charges. The waiver of fees, costs, or charges related to a debt secured by the debtor's principal residence is protected under specific conditions outlined in the law. Failure to comply with these conditions may result in a violation of certain sections. Additionally, a plan can include the option to waive any prepayment penalty on a claim secured by the debtor's principal residence. SEC. 5. CONFIRMATION OF PLAN. Amends Section 1325(a) of title 11, the United States Code, regarding modification of claim rights in a bankruptcy plan. SEC. 6. DISCHARGE. SEC. 6. DISCHARGE. Amends Section 1328 of title 11, the United States Code, regarding payments to holders of modified claims under section 1322(b)(11) and unpaid secured claims. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS. This Act and its amendments will take effect on the enactment date. The amendments will apply to cases under title 11 of the United States Code before, on, or after the enactment date.
